thread.title_full: Why the Sacramento Kings will shock NBA and make playoffs | New York Post

author: Tim Bontemps
title: Why the Sacramento Kings will shock NBA and make playoffs
text:
Over two weeks, The Post will be running through 10 of the hottest issues around the NBA heading into the 2015-16 season. 
Let’s set aside, at least for a few minutes, that the Kings have been the NBA’s most dysfunctional franchise for the better part of a decade, stretching back to the bizarre final few years of the Maloof family’s ownership and continuing through Vivek Ranadive’s past three years controlling the franchise.
Let’s also forget about the bizarre summer the Kings had, which included one of the worst trades in recent NBA history: sending 2014 first-round pick Nik Stauskas, a protected first-round pick and the right to swap two more so the 76ers would swallow the salaries of Jason Thompson and Carl Landry.
Let’s focus instead on the team the Kings have heading into this season, beginning with DeMarcus Cousins, who is legitimately one of the 10 to 12 best players in the NBA. Although Rajon Rondo isn’t the player he was before tearing up his knee, he and Darren Collison are a more-than-competent point guard tandem. The same goes for Ben McLemore and Marco Belinelli at shooting guard, and small forward Rudy Gay had one of the best seasons of his career last year in his first full season in Sacramento.
Combine them with solid depth players such as Kosta Koufos, Omri Casspi and rookie Willie Cauley-Stein — who at least will be able to provide some defense from the get-go — and there’s little doubt the Kings have talent.
George Karl Photo: AP George Karl remains the team’s coach despite spending most of the offseason feuding with Cousins — even working at times to get him traded. Those attempts eventually bled into the public eye and forced upper management, led by Vlade Divac, to try to patch things up.
Though Karl has issues when it comes to the postseason, the man knows how to win games. The last 20 times Karl has coached at least half of an NBA season, he’s won at least 50 percent of his games — and has won 60 percent of his games in 13 of the 20.
The Kings have a roster capable of playing Karl’s preferred style. Sacramento can play small with Gay or Casspi at power forward next to Cousins, and can roll out multiple three-guard lineups with some combination of Rondo, Collison, McLemore and Belinelli.
The top seven spots in the Western Conference playoff race are virtual locks: the Warriors, Spurs, Rockets, Clippers, Thunder, Grizzlies and Pelicans in some order, barring significant injury issues.
But the eighth spot is very much up for grabs. The Lakers are still awful, and the Timberwolves are too reliant on their young talent. The Mavericks appear headed for the lottery — possibly a very high pick — with half their roster injured. The Trail Blazers, after winning the Northwest Division, will plummet to the bottom of the conference after losing four-fifths of their starting lineup. The Suns and Jazz will be in the running, but have issues: Jeff Hornacek’s expiring contract and the tumult surrounding power forward Markieff Morris in Phoenix, the lack of a point guard in Utah.
You can make as strong a case for the Kings snatching that eighth spot as you can any of those other teams, none of which has a player better than Cousins or the depth Sacramento has developed across its roster.
Were the Kings smart in how they tried to retool this summer? No, and that could be problematic in the future. But for a franchise trying to build momentum as it prepares to move into a new downtown arena next summer, those moves could provide them with the playoff berth they’re desperate to achieve.
